column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Recline and Use a Computer
#Text=For people with back problems , where it may be painful and difficult to sit up for any length of time , this article suggests a means to recline while using the computer .
#Text=This system applies primarily to regular PCs with independent keyboards .
#Text=Steps
#Text=What you will need to do .
#Text=Obtain a recliner .
#Text=Cut a board to hold the keyboard .
#Text=Obtain a table to hold the monitor .
#Text=Obtain table to hold the mouse pad .
#Text=Obtain table to hold keyboard .
#Text=Get a recliner generally called a Lazy Boy of the type used by Frasier 's father 's ( TV show ) .
#Text=It reclines to a number of set degrees and a lever raises a leg and foot rest .
#Text=Degree of recline must lock in place .
#Text=These may be found sometimes in thrift stores .
#Text=Keep in mind that new furniture often contains chemicals adverse to the nervous system .
#Text=If you can recline in one of these chairs with your feet up without pain this system maybe for you .
#Text=Separately a locking recliner with independent foot and leg rest may be less expensive and more efficient .
#Text=The chair may be set in a permanent reclining position or adjusted with each sitting .
#Text=If permanent , with the Lazy Boy one may have to step over and between the leg rest brackets each time getting in and out .
#Text=In this case the separate leg rest would be better .
#Text=This system takes a little work but is worth it to be pain free .
#Text=One needs to make a board to sit across the arms of the chair , to hold the keyboard .
#Text=When the chair is in recline , the arms of the chair and thus the keyboard take an angle of about 35 or 40 degrees .
#Text=The idea here is to keep the elbows resting on the arms , whether one types or uses the mouse .
#Text=One needs a keyboard that has the little legs that snap out to hook over the further side of the board , to keep the keyboard from sliding down .
#Text=The keyboard should be able to slide back and fourth on the board for precise adjustment .
#Text=The board may be finish grade fir , by or 1 " x 8 " , where the keyboard is in width .
#Text=A wider board may obtained and cut down lengthwise for special accommodation or customized in any way .
#Text=One may want to round off and sand edges .
#Text=The length of the board should be from half-way across the width of the left arm pad to to half-way across the width of the right arm pad , which could be .
#Text=Then at each end of the board , C clamps are screwed in place , screw lever up , which hooks on the ends of the arms , to keep the board from sliding down .

#Text=The placement of the C Clamps can be used to adjust the distance of the board away from the body , but must be at least two thirds of the way towards the further edge to keep the board from tipping over .
#Text=The length of the chair arm should probably be around .
#Text=The keyboard wire may need an extension , depending on the distance from the computer , and may be looped through a C clamp at one end to keep it draped over the side of the arm .
#Text=This contrivance must be slipped in whole or part over to a side table when one gets up .
#Text=The monitor is set on a table adjusted to a height easy on the eyes with one 's head rested against the back of the chair .
#Text=A nice distance may be about , adjusted to either side of the leg rest or feet .
#Text=However it may be necessary to enlarge the system fonts , which is easier on eyes in any event .
#Text=The mouse pad should be placed on a table to the right or left of the chair , as close as possible to the arm .

#Text=It should be about exactly the same height as the high point of the end of the chair arm when in recline position and at a distance so that one can pivot from the elbow , one 's arm and hand from the keyboard to mouse and back , without the elbow leaving the arm of the chair , and also so as one does not have to reach .
#Text=One can shim the pad base to the proper level .
#Text=Using the side away from any leg rest lever may be no problem .
#Text=However access to the lever may be impaired by the placement of the mouse base .
#Text=A table with an extended top might be obtained so that one can reach under to the lever .
#Text=An extension for the mouse might be required .

#Text=For people with mouse associated problems around the shoulders and neck , one can have mouse stands on both sides of the chair and switch the mouse to either side , assuming one learns to use both hands with the same mouse setting , and not having to change right/left handed system settings each time .
#Text=This system may seem a little funky , but has been used for 6 years with complete success .
#Text=One may be able to improve on the system to suit oneself .
#Text=Finished .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Laptops could be used with the recliner , perhaps with the aid of a big pillow and some contrivance to slide it off to side table , so one does n't have to try to stand up with it .
